Linear Algebra





I have created this website to share my notes, materials, and ideas related to various fields of pure and applied mathematics. If you find any flaws or mistakes, or if you have questions about any ideas or content presented here, please let me know via email—I would greatly appreciate it. You can learn more about me on the About page.

title: About Me
About Me
text:
Short Bio
I am a first-year postgraduate student in Applied Mathematics at Mehran University of Engineering and Technology, Jamshoro (Pakistan).
I completed my undergraduate studies in Mathematics at the same university under the supervision of Dr. Sania Qureshi.
Alongside my formal studies, I am independently learning pure mathematics.
I created this website to share my ideas, notes, and important material related to various areas of Pure and Applied Mathematics.

title: Functions
text:
Functions
Here you write your notes about functions.
Example:
A function is a mapping \(f: A \to B\) such that for each element \(x\) in \(A\) has a unique image in \(B\) that is \(f(x)\). Then consider the following commutative diagram
In mathematical proofs our goal is to assume the hypothesis and prove the conclusions. For instance consider the most iconic things that can happen here. Consider the following function \[ f(x)=\frac{x^2+1}{x^2+1} \] this indeed shows a function. Next consider now consider some in this case we have


Heading 1






NoteDefinition



A function \(f : A \to B\) is a rule that assigns to each \(a \in A\) exactly one element \(f(a) \in B\).








ImportantTheorem



If \(f\) is continuous on \([a,b]\), then \(f\) attains a maximum and minimum on \([a,b]\).








TipProof



The proof follows from the Extreme Value Theorem.



Consider \(f(x)=x^2\) on \([-1,1]\). The maximum is \(1\) and the minimum is \(0\).







WarningExercise



Show that the sum of two continuous functions is continuous.



Theorem 1 (Intermediate Value Theorem).
Let \(f\) be continuous on \([a,b]\)…







TipProof





Show proof

Since \(f\) is continuous on \([a,b]\), by the completeness of \(\mathbb{R}\)…
